title: Minimum Tax in Journey
problem_statement:
Minimum Tax in Journey

Problem Description

Consider a city with toll plazas represented as nodes in an undirected and unrooted tree with n nodes, indexed from 0 to n-1.

The connections between toll plazas are described by the 2D integer array paths, where paths[i] = [a, b] indicates that there is an edge between nodes a and b in the tree.

Each toll plaza has an associated tax, and you are given an integer array tax, where tax[i] represents the tax required to cross node i.

The total tax of any path is defined as the sum of the taxes of all nodes on that path.

Now, you are provided with a 2D integer array journeys, where journeys[i] = [start, end] indicates the ith journey, starting from node start and traveling to node end using any valid path.

Before performing every journey, you can choose some non-adjacent toll plazas and halve the taxes of those plazas.

Your task is to determine the minimum total tax sum to perform all the given journeys.

Input Format

The input is provided in several blocks:

  1. The first line contains an integer n, the number of nodes.
  2. The second line contains an integer representing the number of paths (which will be n-1).
  3. The next n-1 lines each contain two integers, a and b, representing an edge in the tree.
  4. The following line contains an integer representing the size of the tax array (which will be n).
  5. The next n lines each contain an integer representing a tax value tax[i] for node i.
  6. The following line contains an integer representing the number of journeys.
  7. The next n lines (where n is the number of journeys) each contain two integers, start and end, representing a journey.

Output Format

Return an integer, which is the minimum total tax sum to perform all the given journeys.

Constraints

  • 1 <= n <= 50
  • paths.length == n-1
  • 0 <= a, b < n
  • paths represents a valid tree.
  • tax.length == n
  • tax[i] is an even integer.
  • 0 <= tax[i] <= 1000
  • 1 <= journeys.length <= 100
  • 0 <= start, end < n

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
4
3
0 1
0 2
0 3
4
2
4
6
8
2
0 1
2 3
Output:
23

Explanation:

Path 0->3: nodes [0,1,3], base sum 10, best saving = 1 + 3 = 4 -> cost 6

Path 2->1: nodes [2,1], base sum 12, best saving = 5 -> cost 7

Path 0->3: nodes [2,1,3], base sum 18, best saving = 5 + 3 = 8 -> cost 10

Minimum total tax = 6 + 7 + 10 = 23.

Example 2:

Input:
1
0
1
100
1
0 0
Output:
4

Explanation: Only one node with tax 8, start and end are the same, and you can halve it to 4.
